title: A vintage performance from Thongchai - Bangkok Post
text:
A vintage performance from Thongchai 3 Oct 2015 at 01:28 52 viewed 0 comments NEWSPAPER SECTION: SPORTS | WRITER: NOBBY PILES - + Like one of those special Burgundy wines, Thongchai Jaidee simply seems to get better with age. 
Last weekend the 45 year-old Thai golfer displayed nerves of steel as he won his seventh European Tour title after shooting a bogey-free 67 to take the European Open trophy at Bad Griesbach in Germany. 
Television commentators on the Golf Channel were suitably impressed, calling him “The master from Thailand” and “a great champion”. 
The former paratrooper is the oldest winner of the tournament. The victory moved Thongchai to 32nd in the world rankings and eighth in the prestigious Race to Dubai. 
It was also his third win on European soil, his first four titles coming in European Tour events held in Asia. Remarkably, all three of the wins in Europe have come since he turned 40. 
Winning in Europe gives him particular satisfaction. “It’s the third time I’ve won outside Asia, so I’m very happy with that,” he said on Sunday. 
His first success in Europe was the Wales Open in 2012, followed by the 2014 Nordea Masters in Sweden where he outlasted Ryder Cup stars Victor Dubuisson and Stephen Gallacher in an exciting play-off. In fact that was the last victory by an Asian player on the European Tour, until Thongchai achieved it again last week. 
In addition to that he has enjoyed 13 Asian Tour triumphs, topping the tour’s Order of Merit on three occasions. 
Now that’s not bad at all for someone who didn’t turn professional until he was 30. In fact Thongchai didn’t start playing golf until he was 16, something almost unheard of in these days when toddlers are hardly out of the pram before they pick up the clubs. 
It is also a reminder that golf is one sport in which Thailand has produced truly world-class competitors. Thongchai’s win was the third by a Thai on the European Tour this year. The talented Kiradech Aphibarnrat also triumphed in China and Scotland. 
Around the world everyone seems familiar with “Jaidee” as he is known outside of Thailand, and with his pleasant personality he is a great ambassador, not only for golf, but the kingdom itself. 
With his early success in Asia it would have been easy for Thongchai to rest on his laurels and remain in the Orient where he would most likely have piled up the trophies and lived a very comfortable life. 
But he was more ambitious than that, determined to prove himself on a bigger stage, hence his progress on the European Tour. He knew it wouldn’t be easy and it wasn’t. Everything was different — the weather, the culture, the food and the golf courses. 
But he quickly adapted. After his first lengthy spell in Europe he returned to Thailand with renewed confidence. 
“I’ve really enjoyed it in Europe,” he told the Post in 2006. “I’ve learned so much. Everything is different there and the weather can change every day — it’s rainy, then sunny, then windy.” 
Thongchai soon made a lot of friends on the European Tour and found himself playing with the likes of Colin Montgomerie, Paul McGinley, Padraig Harrington, Graeme McDowell and Miguel Angel Jimenez. 
Montgomerie was one of the first to recognise Thongchai’s potential, saying he was the best Asian player he had ever competed against. 
Thongchai appreciated the reception he received In Europe. “Everyone was friendly and I felt very comfortable with players, no matter what nationality.” 
The Thai veteran’s command of English also improved dramatically after a couple of seasons in Europe and that undoubtedly played a part in boosting his confidence, reflected by better displays in tournaments. 
His taste in food also broadened. “I am very lucky because there are Thai restaurants in most European cities,” he said. “But if there isn’t I can eat European food.” 
Thongchai’s golf improved so much he has become a familiar face at the world’s top events and he has now competed in an impressive 27 majors. He caused some consternation there when it was discovered that at his five-star hotel in Tulsa he slept every night on the bedroom floor because the bed was too soft! 
His best result in a major is 13th place at the Open at Turnberry in 2009. 
Thongchai has also played a leading role in representative golf for Asia against Europe in the Royal Trophy and against Japan in the Dynasty Cup. In 2014 he was appointed playing captain of the Asian team in the inaugural EurAsian Cup, and led an Asian fightback on the final day to secure a nail-biting 10-10 draw. 
He has developed into a very consistent tee-to-green player and when his putter, which occasionally lets him down, is hot he’s a threat in any tournament. 
Next week, Thongchai faces a totally new challenge, the Presidents Cup in which he will be playing for the International team against the US in Incheon, South Korea. 
Thongchai will be playing with and against the best golfers in the world, but that won’t bother him — just the opposite in fact. He loves a challenge and you won’t get a bigger challenge than taking on the likes of Jordan Spieth, Bubba Watson, Rickie Fowler and Phil Mickelson. 
The Thai veteran has some pretty useful golfers on his own side too, including Jason Day, Louis Oosthuizen, Adam Scott and Charle Schwartzel. 
Thongchai is a true professional and has the mental strength to know he can compete with the best. Despite his success, Thongchai remains a humble man and devoted to his family, wife (and manager) Namfon, and their two boys, Titituch and Kittituch.
